data.title: GSK's Pipeline Has to Prove It Can Counter Concerns Over Vaccine Business — Market Talk
data.description: GSK has to prove its pipeline is packed with new blockbuster treatments to withstand investors' concerns over its vaccine business slowdown in China and the U.S., AJ Bell investment director Russ Mould says. Further worries over the likely appointment of vaccine-sceptic Robert F Kennedy Jr. as Secretary of Health and Human Services in the U.S. still linger, he says. The British pharma giant's posted a second consecutive drop in sales in the fourth quarter, driven by a 19% decline in sales of its flu shots and a 52% plunge for its respiratory treatment Arexvy. Shares are up 6.7% at 14.73 pounds.(helena.smolak@wsj.com)

data.title: SPIRE INC SEC 10-Q Report
data.description:
Spire Inc., a leading natural gas utility company, has released its Form 10-Q report for the third quarter, detailing both financial and operational performance. The report highlights the company's efforts in maintaining operational efficiency and strategic investments in infrastructure, despite facing challenges such as lower natural gas prices.

Financial Highlights

Spire Inc. reported the following key financial metrics for the third quarter:

  • Operating Revenues: $669.1 million, reflecting a decrease from $756.6 million in the prior year period, primarily due to lower natural gas prices.
  • Operating Income: $148.8 million, an increase from $139.2 million in the prior year period, indicating improved operational efficiency.
  • Net Income: $81.3 million, compared to $85.1 million in the prior year period, impacted by lower other income.
  • Net Income Available to Common Shareholders: $77.5 million, down from $81.3 million in the prior year period, reflecting the impact of preferred dividends.
  • Basic Earnings Per Common Share: $1.34, compared to $1.52 in the prior year period, due to a higher number of shares outstanding.
  • Diluted Earnings Per Common Share: $1.34, compared to $1.52 in the prior year period, consistent with the basic earnings per share.

Business Highlights

Spire Inc. provided an overview of its business performance, focusing on its core segments and geographical operations:

  • Gas Utility Segment Performance: The Gas Utility segment, which includes Spire Missouri, Spire Alabama, and Spire EnergySouth, remains the core business segment of Spire Inc., contributing significantly to the company's earnings. This segment is primarily driven by the regulated natural gas distribution operations across Missouri, Alabama, and parts of Mississippi.
  • Geographical Performance - Spire Missouri: Spire Missouri, the largest natural gas distribution utility in Missouri, serves major areas including St. Louis and Kansas City. The utility's performance is heavily influenced by the seasonal demand for heating energy, with earnings typically concentrated during the heating season from November through April.
  • Geographical Performance - Spire Alabama: Spire Alabama, the largest natural gas distribution utility in Alabama, serves central and northern regions, including Birmingham and Montgomery. The utility's operations are regulated by the Alabama Public Service Commission, and it continues to focus on providing reliable service to its customer base.
  • Gas Marketing Segment: Spire Marketing operates in the non-regulated marketing of natural gas across the U.S. and into Canada. It manages transactions with producers, municipalities, and large commercial customers, leveraging firm transportation and storage contracts to optimize its operations.
  • Midstream Segment Expansion: The Midstream segment includes Spire Storage, Spire STL Pipeline, and the recently acquired Spire MoGas Pipeline. The acquisition of MoGas Pipeline, a 263-mile FERC-regulated natural gas pipeline, enhances Spire's capacity to deliver gas to growing customer bases in Missouri.
  • Operational Focus: Spire Inc. continues to focus on infrastructure investments and system reliability to support its regulated operations. The company is actively engaged in regulatory processes to ensure recovery of prudent costs and investments through rate adjustments.
  • Future Outlook: Management anticipates continued growth in the Gas Utility segment, driven by infrastructure investments and regulatory support. The company is also focused on optimizing its Gas Marketing and Midstream operations to enhance overall performance.

SEC Filing: SPIRE INC [ SR ] - 10-Q - Feb. 05, 2025

data.title: SSR Mining's Price Target, Stock Rating Upgraded by RBC Capital Markets; Shares Up 14%
data.description:
SSR Mining's price target has been increased to US$8 from US$5.50 while its stock rating was upgraded to Sector Perform from Underperform, RBC Capital Markets said in a Wednesday note.

RBC said the upgrade is based on its view that rising prices and cash flow from the portfolio (now including Cripple Creek & Victor ahead of expected deal close in Q1 2025, 20% of NAV) limit downside, even as the bank continues to model no value/production for the company's Turkish assets, including the Copper mine

"The key question for the stock remains Copler, however, and the ultimate outcome in Turkey," RBC said. "We have no further information as to a specific outcome, total costs, or potential timeline to a restart, which informs our lower target multiples vs. peers and our Sector Perform rating."

Despite the better outlook and potential upside, RBC thinks investors need more clarity on the outcome in Turkey before getting more comfortable with the valuation and outlook.

"A positive outcome (vs. our assumptions) could lead us to revise our thesis, as could incremental visibility into upside at other operations," RBC said.

SSR's share price jumped 14% at last look to $13.37 on the TSX.

data.title: Metals Exploration Extends GBP5.5 Million Loan Facility
data.description:
Metals Exploration extended the maturity date of its 5.5 million-pound-sterling unsecured bridging term loan facility with its 12.4% shareholder, Drachs Investments No 3, to March 31 from Jan. 31.

The London-listed gold exploration company said Wednesday the facility's other terms, including its 10% annual interest rate, remain unchanged.

The loan agreement is part of Metals Exploration's recently completed 67.5 million-pound takeover of Condor Gold.

data.title: BMO on Canada's International Trade Surplus
data.description:
Canada's merchandise trade balance Wednesday posted a C$708 million surplus in December from a downwardly revised shortfall of C$986 million in November, noted Bank of Montreal (BMO).

In total, the full-year trade deficit deepened to C$7.2 billion from C$600 million in 2023, as growth in exports (+1.0%) was outpaced by imports (+1.9%).

There were a lot of moving parts in December, especially since it was the first full month since United States President Donald Trump started threatening Canada with 25% tariffs to begin in January, said the bank. While investors have some more details on his tariff plans since then — and the near-miss to start February — in many ways, the trade landscape remains just as uncertain.

As a consequence, BMO expects front-running ahead of tariffs will add additional noise to the data until tariffs are implemented or their threat dissipates.

Exports jumped 4.9% month over month, their largest increase in almost a year. Growth was broad-based but led by energy (+9.5%, partially on higher prices) and metal and non-metallic mineral products (+9.2%). Meantime, imports rose 2.3%, again with increases across most product categories.

In volume terms, exports increased 11.6% a.r. while imports were up 8.6% a.r. in Q4. It looks like trade will add to Q4 gross domestic product growth when investors get the latter report at the end of the month, pointed out the bank.

Separately, the services trade shortfall narrowed from C$443 million to C$67 million in December, its smallest gap since entering deficit territory in late summer. Canada's overall trade balance — goods plus services — improved from a C$1.4 billion deficit to a C$600 million surplus in December.

Canada's normally volatile trade figures are subject to even more noise given tariff uncertainty at the turn of the year, stated BMO. Tariff front-running likely contributed to December's increase in trade activity, with the weaker Canadian dollar (CAD or loonie) providing a helping hand, supporting economic growth to end 2024.

The bank wouldn't be surprised if the early 2025 trade figures are subject to heightened volatility, not unlike broader financial markets, as investors await more certainty on the U.S. trade tariff front.

data.title: USDA Reports Flash Sale of Corn to Mexico — Market Talk
data.description: As the U.S. and Mexico grapple over tariff threats, Mexico is continuing to purchase U.S. corn exports — with the USDA confirming sales of 330,000 metric tons of corn for delivery to Mexico during the 2025/26 marketing year. Corn and soybean futures on the CBOT are lower in early trading, with the last-minute nature of agreements to delay implementing tariffs keeping investors in markets on edge. "[His] eleventh-hour decision to delay the 25% tariffs he had threatened to impose on Canada and Mexico is a good reminder of his unpredictable nature," says Paul Ashworth of Capital Economics in a note, adding that the firm expects the Trump administration to move forward on a 10% universal tariff, as well as higher tariffs on Chinese goods. (kirk.maltais@wsj.com)

data.title: This is how much Mattel's $600 million buyback could boost earnings
data.description:
By James Rogers

Mattel is ramping up its share repurchase efforts. Analyst firm UBS expects an earnings boost from the toy maker.

Mattel Inc. announced plans to repurchase $600 million shares in 2025 when the toy maker reported its fourth-quarter results late Tuesday. Analyst firm UBS said that the better-than-expected buyback could provide a significant earnings boost to the El Segundo, Calif.-based company.

In a note released Wednesday UBS analyst Arpiné Kocharyan wrote that Mattel's (MAT) $600 million buyback target was ahead of investor expectations. UBS estimated that every $100 million of share repurchases could add 3 cents to 4 cents to Mattel's earnings per share.

Mattel's stock is up 15.7% Wednesday, boosted by the company's better-than-expected outlook and its plans to navigate tariffs from President Trump. The stock is on pace for its largest daily percentage increase since Feb. 8, 2019, when it rose 23.22%, according to Dow Jones Market Data.

Related: Mattel's stock rallies, as outlook for profits - and Barbie - outweigh potential tariff impact

In a conference call to discuss the results, Mattel CFO Anthony DiSilvestro said that the company has been "very active" on the buyback front. "We resumed repurchases in 2023," he said, noting that the company repurchased $200 million in shares in 2023 and $400 million in 2024. "Now, we're accelerating to a targeted level of $600 million in 2025," he added. "And we have built in the benefit of that in terms of the lower share count and the benefit to EPS."

For 2025, Mattel expects adjusted earnings of $1.66 to $1.72 a share, surpassing the FactSet consensus estimate of $1.57 a share.

UBS analyst Kocharyan wrote that Mattel's guidance coming in ahead of expectations, despite the impact of newly announced tariffs, suggests "underlying upside was higher." UBS has a buy rating and $26 price target for Mattel.

Related: Toy-maker stocks drop, but here's why tariffs aren't really much of a threat to them

In a note released Wednesday J.P. Morgan analyst Christopher Horvers described Mattel's guidance as solid. "Notably, MAT included anticipated impacts of tariffs and mitigating actions in its 2025 guidance," he wrote. J.P. Morgan has a neutral rating and $23 price target for Mattel.

The U.S. implemented an additional 10% tariff on Chinese goods this week, prompting retaliatory tariffs from China.

Speaking during the conference call to discuss the results, Mattel CFO DiSilvestro said that the company has been "continuously optimizing and diversifying" its manufacturing footprint over the past several years. "Today, we source products from seven different countries," he said. In 2025 Mattel expects China will represent less than 40% of global production for the company's toys, compared with an industry average of about 80%, DiSilvestro added.

Related: Barbie boom fades at Mattel, but Hot Wheels - and adult collectors - are on an upswing

With the U.S. representing about half of Mattel's global toy sales, the company's tariff exposure in the U.S. related to China should be about 20% of global production, according to the CFO.

The U.S. had also planned to start collecting new 25% tariffs on goods imported from Mexico and Canada this week. However, on Monday, Trump said that the Mexican and Canadian tariffs have been paused for roughly one month.

DiSilvestro said that Mattel sources less than 10% of its toys from Mexico and has no sourcing from Canada. "By 2027, no single country is expected to represent more than about 25% of total global production or about half of that in terms of U.S. sales," he added.

Related: Mattel's quarterly sales fell. But the months ahead will be better, executives say.

Mattel shares have risen 11.3% in the last 12 months, compared with the S&P 500 index's SPX gain of 20.6%.

Bill Peters contributed.

-James Rogers

This content was created by MarketWatch, which is operated by Dow Jones & Co. MarketWatch is published independently from Dow Jones Newswires and The Wall Street Journal.

data.title: Gold miners up as bullion prices edge higher
data.description:
** Shares of gold miners up as bullion prices continue their record run

** Spot gold up 1.9% at $2,875.49/ounce, after hitting a record high of $2,877/ounce earlier in the session

** Gold prices rose as investors sought the safe-haven asset amid escalating concerns about the U.S.-China trade war and its potential impact on economic growth

** Earlier this week, China retaliated by imposing tariffs on U.S. goods in response to new U.S. tariffs

** Top miner Newmont and Barrick Gold up 4.4% and 2.3%, respectively

** U.S.-listed shares of South African miners Gold Fields up 4.4%, Harmony Gold rises 1.8% and AngloGold Ashanti up 3.4%

** Shares of Canadian miners Agnico Eagle Mines .TO> and Kinross Gold .TO> up 3.1% and 2.6%, respectively

data.title: US Natgas Prices Steady on Wednesday
data.description:
US natural gas futures stood at $3.2/MMBtu as forecasts for milder weather and lower demand this week offset expectations of higher demand next week.

Average gas output in the Lower 48 states rose to 106.0 bcfd in February, surpassing January's 102.7 bcfd and December’s record 104.6 bcfd.

However, daily output dropped to 105.3 bcfd on Wednesday from a record 106.5 bcfd on Jan. 31.

Last week’s extreme cold drove heating demand to a record high, possibly leading to a record gas storage withdrawal.

Meanwhile, gas flows to US LNG export plants hit 15.0 bcfd in February, surpassing January’s 14.6 bcfd and December’s record 14.7 bcfd.

data.title: Street View: Enphase Energy to face weak demand in 2025 despite upbeat Q1 forecast
data.description:
** Solar inverter maker Enphase Energy forecast Q1 revenue above market estimates on Tuesday, after robust demand helped it post a better-than-expected Q4 operating profit

** Fifteen of 39 brokerages rate the stock "buy" or higher, 21 "hold" and 3 "sell" or lower; their median PT is $81 - data compiled by LSEG

** ENPH shares up 1.4% at $67.71 on Wednesday

CHOPPY DEMAND DESPITE 4Q24 BEAT

** Morgan Stanley ("Equal-Weight") cuts PT to $67 from $68, says demand appears shaky at best, with management highlighting a "stable" U.S. market and a mixed Europe market

** Brokerage says "tariff uncertainty could raise the hurdle for additional Fed cuts, which is a key catalyst for stronger demand in the U.S."

** BMO ("Market Perform") cuts PT to $66 from $69, says that demand remains weaker than expected and implies estimates likely need to come down again

** Jefferies ("Underperform") cuts PT to $54 from $57, says that while the U.S. market continues a slow but steady recovery, the EU market is expected to be weak through 2025

** TD Cowen cuts PT to $94 from $100, RBC cuts PT to $63 from $71

data.title: LionHeart Family Institute Raises Concerns Over Academic Pressures on Christian Researchers
data.description:
Jacksonville, Florida--(Newsfile Corp. - February 5, 2025) - The LionHeart Family Institute has expressed concerns about mounting pressures on researchers who explore controversial topics in child health and family studies. According to the organization, several academics have recently faced professional challenges—ranging from temporary suspensions to heightened scrutiny—for conducting research that questions mainstream academic perspectives on gender identity, child psychology, and related fields.

Temporary Suspensions and Increased Scrutiny

Over the past week, three professors from prominent universities have been placed on temporary leave. The professors' work, according to LionHeart, focused on examining how family values and religious beliefs shape child development and health outcomes. In addition to their suspensions, these scholars have reportedly come under increased scrutiny from private consultants and advocacy groups who question their research methodologies and the sources of their funding.

Daryl Wilson, spokesperson for LionHeart, stated, "There is a growing trend of silencing academic voices that offer alternative perspectives. Instead of encouraging open dialogue, certain institutions appear to be curbing the freedom to investigate and share findings that diverge from dominant ideologies."

The organization asserts that this atmosphere of scrutiny deters researchers from pursuing studies that could offer valuable insights into family-centered approaches to child well-being, including the role of religion, traditional family structures, and non-mainstream therapeutic methods.

Concerns About Research Funding Bias

LionHeart Family Institute has further raised concerns about the allocation of research funding in child health and psychology. The group contends that many grant opportunities prioritize studies that affirm certain medical and psychological interventions for minors, such as gender-affirming treatments, while studies supported by religious or family-oriented foundations often face additional hurdles.

"Many academic institutions and funding bodies seem to favor research that aligns with prevailing social and political agendas," said Dr. John Leo Grimani, CEO of LionHeart Family Institute. "Researchers exploring different paradigms—particularly those informed by faith-based values or traditional family dynamics—often find it difficult to secure funding or gain acceptance within the academic community."

Grimani added that the uneven distribution of resources and attention creates a research environment where some voices are amplified while others are marginalized. "Scientific inquiry should be grounded in empirical evidence and ethical consideration. It must also allow room for a range of approaches. When funding structures and institutional pressures skew heavily in one direction, it undermines the principles of academic fairness and intellectual diversity," he said.

A Call for Academic Freedom and Neutrality

In light of these challenges, LionHeart Family Institute is calling on universities and research institutions to uphold the principles of academic freedom and impartiality. The organization emphasizes the importance of fostering an environment where researchers can freely investigate topics without fear of reprisal, provided they adhere to rigorous ethical and methodological standards.

"Academic freedom is not just about protecting individual scholars; it's about ensuring that the academic community as a whole remains a place where diverse ideas can flourish," said Grimani. "When institutions take a neutral stance and allow data-driven research to speak for itself, everyone benefits—students, families, policymakers, and society at large."

LionHeart also urged institutions to resist external pressures, whether from advocacy groups, private consultants, or other organizations. The group suggested that universities establish clearer guidelines and stronger safeguards to protect researchers from undue influence or retaliation.

Ensuring Open Scientific Debate

The broader message from LionHeart Family Institute is a plea for open and robust scientific discourse. While acknowledging that controversial topics can spark intense debate, the organization insists that the solution is not to silence dissenting views but to engage with them in a constructive manner.

"Open scientific debate is the foundation of progress," Grimani concluded. "Without it, we risk turning academic institutions into echo chambers rather than spaces for true intellectual exploration. We stand for a balanced approach that values all evidence-based perspectives and upholds the integrity of the scientific process."

The LionHeart Family Institute plans to continue advocating for these principles at conferences, in publications, and through ongoing dialogues with academic leaders. By championing a fair, open, and unbiased research environment, the organization hopes to contribute to a culture of inquiry that serves the common good and supports the well-being of children and families everywhere.

Media Contact:

LionHeart Family Institute Press Office

+1-415-559-0665

Office@lionheartfamilyinstitute.com

lionheartfamilyinstitute.com

To view the source version of this press release, please visit https://www.newsfilecorp.com/release/239110

data.title: Italy's ReGuest Names New Marketing Chief
data.description:
ReGuest (REGU.VI) appointed Johannes Tappeiner as its new chief marketing officer, effective Feb. 10.

Denis Pellegrini most recently held the role but will now focus on his chief sales officer position at the hotels-focused customer relationship management company.

data.title: Vaxcyte Advances Phase 2 Study on Infant Pneumococcal Disease Prevention to Final Stage
data.description:
Vaxcyte said Wednesday its ongoing phase 2 study assessing VAX-31 for the prevention of invasive pneumococcal disease in infants is advancing to its second and final stage.

The company said participants who received VAX-31 in the first stage will continue the standard dosing regimen as part of the second stage.

Vaxcyte said it expects to release topline data from the study's primary three-dose immunization series in the middle of next year, followed by topline data from the booster dose about nine months later.

In infants, the VAX-31 was designed to cover about 94% of invasive pneumococcal disease and roughly 93% of acute otitis media caused by streptococcus pneumoniae in children under five years old in the United States.

Shares of Vaxcyte were up nearly 3% in recent trading.
